comments.commentBody: Krugman was careful not to use the scatter to argue FOR Keynsian theories, which he does elsewhere and in other ways. He is arguing that you cannot ignore the scatter as a whole while cherry-picking a few outliers to argue AGAINST Keynsian theories, which is what he is accusing Sacks of.

This lament is one of the most direct ever on the intractability of the Republican position vis-à-vis reality. But let's not kid ourselves that the facts will somehow enlighten anyone, as what's described here is unfortunately another hideous example of:
"It is difficult to get a man to understand something, when his salary depends on his not understanding it.." (Upton Sinclair).
This is the political face of a Plutocracy in the ascendant, ever dismissive of facts that don't feed their own narrow and self-serving interests.
If one of the brothers trained at an Al Qaeda camp in Yemen, why was he roaming the streets? He should be doing life without parole.

baron an embarrassment.  As if after the financial crisis and Great Conservative Recession was caused by people intentionally taking vacations instead of failed conservative economic ideas, policies, and market ideology making a hash out of sane oversight of the public's economy.  Just pathetic.

Government printing and spending money may temporarily increase GDP.  As history has shown, after the government stimulus is gone, the jobs that went with it are gone.  If the private sector is not able to increase permanent employment, then the society may canibalize into a civil war.  Greece unemployment rate of 25% is unsustainable without major dislocations, which is they're turning to Socialists and Communists.  Unless they have fairy dust to erase their debt and lower bond prices, they will stay with the Euro and required budgets.
Now would be a time for religious leaders from all faiths to get together and issue an unequivocal condemnation of violence in god's name. I bet they're getting ready to do that right now.

This is ridiculous. Expand your news sources; now: read the BBC, The Guardian, the French press. All of the imams at the major mosques of France have spoken out; there was a publicly celebrated interfaith service at the Grande Mosque of Paris today. The religiously committed Islamic community in France has spoken in one voice of pain, outrage, and disavowal. Google and read the imam, Dalil Boubakeur's remarks and stop stoking the flames of ignorance, fear and hatred. Please.

Wow. That is an eye-opener.

Mahathir Mohamad, the man behind the terrorist sympathizing above, was the prime minister of Malaysia from 1981 to 2003 -- the longest serving leader of a country of some 30 million people. The quote seems authentic, appearing in a Jan. 8 article from Bernama, Malaysia's government news agency: http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v7/bu/newsmarkets.php?id=1099045.

It seems that mainstream Muslim leaders are not unanimously coming out in force against this attack.

I've been a part of the community college system for the last decade as a professor and advisor.   We as a nation do not want to answer your question.  The big tragedy is K-12, as you say.  Community colleges have to make up for everything that has gone on before we see them.  Many students labor under tremendous odds and walls of obstacles to succeed. I've long noted that my favorite work day is commencement for the graduates and their families.  I'm a fan of this effort as a piece of the story to help our nation compete in the years ahead.  The "same old same old" was not going to be a game changer on its own, I'm happy to see that the Haslem administration undertook the challenge.  For the President to highlight a educational initiative of a Republican Governor shows how they are both putting students, families, and our nation ahead of the poisonous politics that are holding us back.

So the most interesting aspect of the incoming republican congress will be the kind of "bipartisan" legislation that will masquerade (full of lies?) as genuine law making. When will the "Entitlements" come under their cooperation with President Obama? Will the Senate Democrats employ the filibuster,  or better yet, the anonymous no vote hold that is available to any member of that chamber? This would only be fair to President Obama and not force him to veto everything. I doubt that he would mind either way. But the 2016 bet that the Republicans will dance thenselves into the wilderness would only fail if and when the Democratic members of Congress comtinue their abject panic and confusion by accepting any debate or false compromises from the loaded gun of their conservative opposites. It should be very interesting teleplay politics.

You are right...but the West is not just ignoring those atrocities.  The West (US Gov, Britain, France, and others) is ACTIVELY aiding many of these terrorists by funding and supplying them, in their obsession with subjugating Syria and every other country that does not bow to them. They do not care if those Muslim radicals they arm turn around and commit savage atrocities, even in the West. We are all accomplices by paying taxes and remaining silent while this goes on.  Saudi Arabia is a great ally of the US, and they are behind many of these terror groups. Why should the world listen to the moans of "innocent" Westerners? This is all common knowledge, and yet continues to happen daily.
So I guess I have to go to BuzzFeed if I want to see some of the most important details of this story?
Same thing in NYC with Eric Garner. I can't understand why they don't give any aid.

This 'publish the cartoons' stuff I really find totally ridiculous. Newspapers are supposed to report the news, not become a participant in the news. I am going to stop buying a newspaper the day it starts propagandizing anything, whether it be free speech, motherhood, or apple pie.

When Larry Flint was shot by a fanatic of some sort or another, should media outlets have published excerpts of the most offensive parts of Screw magazine in solidarity with his free speech challenges to authority?

does not matter if the cartoon is in bad taste, freedom of expression is just that - freedom of expression. All the cartoons should be published by all the papers all over the world to prove that fact no matter how horrible, in bad taste or nasty.

No, there has been countless studies done demonstrating that lowering the intake of certain foods increases health, lowers chances of sickness, and disease. Diabetes, heart disease and some forms of cancer, have been shown to be completely diet related. And what's amazing is that these sicknesses caused by diets can be passed down genetically, and reversed genetically. Read it yourself.

The reality is, most people are in control of their basic health, but choose to blame it on their genes, because blaming it on something they obviously can't control is much easier than taking responsibility for their actions. Being lazy, even about one's own health, is something that Americans are fascinatingly good at. No wonder we have the lowest life-expectancy in all the First World Nations, and we're one of the fattest countries in all the first world nations.
Agreed. Thank you.

.
.

#JeSuisCharlie
#JeSuisAhmed

Mr. Banquet is wrong. The cartoons were gratuitous insults. But after the murders they are now hard news.

The New York Times is considered, by both the public and the newspaper editors, to be the newspaper of record.

Where are the cartoons for the record?
I guess that our right to know would include showing the cartoons that were so offensive. Do you agree?
Elegantly argued, Max. Thank you.

There is no counter claim that we could possibly be surprised to have to make. Drunks are always going to propose the preposterous. And the Republicans are certainly drunk with power. Nothing could, or should surprise anyone in the next 2 years.
Reminds me of a line from my youth, "Brave men run in my family."

Count me as someone who is also disappointed in the NYT's decision. If the reason was ultimately based on Baquet's concern that to publish the cartoons would be offensive to some Muslim readers, that is a pretty weak argument. As other commentators have pointed out, the NYT publishes articles every day that offend one person or group or another. If you're not offending someone you're probably not doing your job. It's sad to see the deliberate narrowing of the motto "All the news that's fit to print."

Dear NYT,

I understand the fact that you didn't publish the cartoons. They could endanger your journalists who provides us our news. The cartoons could be offending for people of some beliefs. It's harsh to see your prophet looking ridiculous. But never should anyone be killed because of an offending cartoon and that's what happened. The New York Times the greatest paper in the world should not retreat because of the offensiveness of the cartoons. You should publish them because they are newsworhty especially at this time when the freedom of expression is under attack. If you publish them you don't say you agree with them, you just show to your readers the reason why those people in Paris where killed. That's why you should publish them.
